newsitem.title: UK: First S.African subsidiary enters Eurorand sector.
newsitem.headline: First S.African subsidiary enters Eurorand sector.

text.p: The first South African-based subsidiary entered the Eurorand market on Tuesday with the launch of a 100 million rand four-year Eurobond.

German chemicals and drugs group subsidiary Bayer Pty Ltd -- which is wholly-owned and has a support agreement from its parent Bayer AG -- launched the deal via lead manager Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in London.
The paper pays a 15.375 percent coupon.
"There is ongoing demand for Eurorand paper," Deutsche Morgan Grenfell syndicate manager Roger Bates said.

"There are investors who are taking the view South African interest rates will decline in the medium-term, so with a four-year issue such as today, there is the possibility of capital appreciation," Bates said.
"Investors will therefore want to be sure of their credit, and Bayer certainly fits the bill," he said.

He added other investors were trying to recoup some of the foreign exchange losses incurred by the depreciation of the rand. But the rand has recently strengthened against the dollar and was quoted at 4.5700/05 on the dollar at 1615 GMT.
Bayer AG is rated Aa2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by Standard & Poor's Corp.
Last January, Bayer AG announced its intention to shift chrome chemical production from Germany to South Africa.

This year has already seen the launch of a number of new Eurorand issues from banks such as Deutsche Bank, ING Bank NV, Rabobank, Westdeutsche Landesbank GZ, supranationals such as Eurofima, European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the International Finance Corp, World Bank, from the corporate General Electric Capital Corp and the sovereign borrower Austria.
